title: Send Silence Packing
description: Send Silence Packing is a traveling exhibit through Active Minds National to raise suicide awareness and hopefully connect people to the care that they may need. The display consists of about a thousand backpacks that will be spread throughout the quad to represent college students that have been lost to suicide.

title: Through the Eyes and Lives of Crows: Opportunities and Challenges of Anthropogenic Change
description:
Speaker: Anne B. Clark, Professor of Biological Sciences, Binghamton University
Anthropogenic change, especially urbanization and climate change, is challenging all organisms, including humans, to adapt. Evolutionary ecologists predict that behaviorally more flexible animals, especially those that learn and transmit information socially, will adapt most successfully. Crows and ravens (Corvus sp.) fit this idea of behaviorally flexible, generalist species with plenty of cognitive capacity; indeed, a number of Corvus species are now well-established in urban areas worldwide.
Based on her thirty-year study of one population in Ithaca, New York, Clark will introduce the complex social world of American crows, how they do or don't fit the expected "urban adaptor" and also how even small cities are dynamic environments that continue to challenge them. Clark will also extend the discussion to crow species globally, the scientific and ecological value of this surprisingly diverse group, and the possibility that many crow species could disappear in the face of complacency and anthropogenic change.
Clark received her PhD in evolutionary biology at the University of Chicago. Her lab researches ecology and evolution of non-human animal social behaviors.
Light refreshments will be served.
location: Young Research Library - Main Conference Room 11360

title: Center for Jewish Studies Lecture with Caroline Luce
description: Caroline Luce (UCLA) will present a lecture for the UCLA Alan D. Leve Center for Jewish Studies entitled, “The Bund in the Borderlands.” This lecture is part our Jewish Los Angles lecture series.
location: Royce Hall Conf/Seminar -  - Herbert Morris Seminar Room 306

description:
6th Annual Going Global Conference on Global Justice, Equity, and Empowerment: Understanding and Enacting Social Change.
Dr. Floridalma Boj Lopez of CSU Northridge will be the keynote speaker.

title: Anoushka Shankar
description:
Sitar player and composer Anoushka Shankar is a singular figure in the Indian classical and progressive world music scenes. Deeply rooted in the Indian classical music tradition, she studied exclusively from the age of 9 under her father and guru, the late Ravi Shankar, and made her professional debut as a classical sitarist at the age of 13. As an international solo artist, she has performed in a range of distinguished venues around the world including Carnegie Hall, Barbican Centre, Sydney Opera House, Vienna Konzerthaus, Théâtre des Champs-Elysées and Palais des Beaux-Arts.
Through her bold and collaborative approach as a composer, Anoushka has encouraged cross-cultural dialogue while demonstrating the versatility of the sitar across musical genres. As a result, she has created a vital body of work with a prominent and diverse roster of artists including Sting, M.I.A., Herbie Hancock, Pepe Habichuela, and her half-sister Norah Jones.

title: Pakistani Culture Show
description:
The SoCal Pakistani Culture Show is an annual event hosted by the Pakistani Student Associations across Southern California. This will be the 11th annual culture show, to be hosted by the UCLA Pakistani Student Association where USC, UCI, UCR and UCSD will be participating schools.
The event aims to celebrate Pakistani culture through dance performances, videos and skits. It is also a one of its kind event which provides a rare opportunity for the Southern California Pakistani community to engage and connect. This year’s theme is “Celebrating Musical Diversity in Pakistan”. Dance performances will focus on how different forms of music have impacted the post-colonial Pakistan history.
Dinner will be served to all attendees.

title: Climate Change on Trial
description:
Today's young people and their children and grandchildren will bear the brunt of global warming. The effects American communities are experiencing today – heat waves, sea-level rise, extreme rainfall, crop failures, and wildfires – will worsen over time.
In 2015, 21 youth plaintiffs filed suit against the federal government, arguing that by subsidizing fossil fuels and failing to control greenhouse gas emissions the United States is violating the children's constitutional rights to life, liberty, and property. The innovative case, Juliana v. United States, has survived two appeals to the U.S. Supreme Court, but government lawyers continue to fight to prevent the case from ever heading to trial.
At an Earth Day event hosted by UCLA School of Law's Emmett Institute on Climate Change and the Environment, Julia Olson, Executive Director and Chief Legal Counsel for Our Children's Trust, and lead attorney for the youth plaintiffs, will deliver an evening lecture to discuss this groundbreaking case. Olson's work has been profiled in 60 Minutes, The Washington Post, CNN, Vogue, NPR, and many other leading media outlets. University of Oregon Law Professor Mary Wood told The New York Times, "she has built not just a case, but a movement."
Following the lecture, UCLA Emmett Institute Faculty Director and Shapiro Law Professor Ann Carlson will moderate a discussion and Q&A with the speaker. A reception will precede the event.
This event is co-sponsored by UCLA Institute of the Environment and Sustainability, UCLA Sustainability, and the UCLA Sustainable LA Grand Challenge.

title: 12th Spring Salsa Celebration feat. Pablo Mendez Latin Band
description:
Salsa Lessons 7:30pm
Latin Culture/Mexican Culture Night: performances of traditional Mexican Dance and Music performed by UCLA students/faculty 8:50pm-9:10pm
Salsa Dance Celebration: two 60 minute Latin concerts 9:10pm-10:10pm, 10:30pm-11:30pm featuring professional salsa band led by violinist, Pablo Mendez for Salsa/Latin Social Dancing.
During band break, high school and college Salsa/Latin Dance Troupes will perform 10:10pm-10:30pm.

title: CrossCheck Live: University Governance and the Right to Protest
description: Featuring prominent UCLA faculty members, senior administrators, and outside scholars, this will be another entry of Vice Chancellor Jerry Kang's (VC for Equity, Diversity and Inclusion) signature event series, CrossCheck Live. Join us for a moderated discussion of university governance and people's right to protest on college campuses.

title: Theater of the Oppressed for Racial Justice
description:
Theater of the Oppressed for Racial Justice
Internationally acclaimed Theater of the Oppressed (TO) groups Co do Brasil and Madalena Anastacia will share their Forum Theater performances with the audience, inviting people into the action to rehearse strategies for resisting ant-black racism and sexism. Leading TO scholar Barbara Santos will perform and make her newly translated work Roots & Wings available, the first book about TO available in English by an Afro-Brazilian feminist author.
Sponsored by SOAA Office of Diversity, Equity & Inclusion, the UCLA Art and Global Health Center, UCLA Prison Education Program, the UCLA Department of World Arts & Cultures/Dance, the School of Arts and Architecture and the Office of Instructional Development.
location: Glorya Kaufman Hall Venue - Dance Theater - Room 200

title: UCLA Extension Restaurant Industry Conference
description: Annual Restaurant Industry Conference. Speakers TBD.

title: Improving Emergency First Response for Individuals in Behavioral Crises
description:
Speaker: Harold Pollack, Helen Ross Professor of Public Policy and Social Service Administration, University of Chicago
Men and women who experience severe mental illness and other challenges face increased risks of having a violent encounter with police officers and other first responders. Pollack will describe strategies to improve emergency response to such incidents and present promising strategies to reduce the risk of such violent encounters.
Pollack received his BS in electrical engineering and computer science from Princeton University and MA and PhD in public policy at Harvard University. He is Co-Director of The University of Chicago Crime Lab.
location: Young Research Library - Main Conference Room 11360

title: Graham Haynes: Music Beyond Music
description: American cornetist, trumpeter, and composer Graham Haynes speaks about his life as an improviser and composer. He also discusses the theory and concept of Conduction, a process and practice developed by Lawrence D. “Butch” Morris. This concept is explored by UCLA students during workshops which are followed by a concert led by Graham Haynes.

title: QScholars Undergraduate Research Symposium
description:
Q Scholars of UCLA is an undergraduate students organization that annually presents Q Scholars Undergraduate Research Symposium provides a safe space for self-identifying LGBTQ+ undergraduate students to present their research on queer issues and/or topics that is not always widely accepted in academia. This year's theme is "Our Existence is Resistance: [Art]iculating our Lives, Identities, and Activism in the New Millennium."
Keynote speaker: Alicia Billalobos, a UCLA alumni who currently works in the LA LGBT Center under the law and policy wing.
location: Young Research Library - Main Conference Room 11360

title: Culture Fix: Saroya Corbett on New Orleans Second Line Parades
description:
Saroya Corbett is a UCLA World Arts and Cultures/Dance graduate student conducting research on bounce dance in New Orleans and majorette performance in Baton Rouge. In this gallery talk, Corbett incorporates Pableaux Johnson’s photographs of Second Line parades as she reflects on her recent fieldwork in New Orleans for Mardi Gras 2019.
Related Exhibition: New Orleans Second Line Parades: Photographs by Pableaux Johnson
Louisiana native Pableaux Johnson has been photographing Second Lines—or Sunday brass band parades—in New Orleans for over a decade. This exhibition presents more than 40 color portraits of members of African American Social Aid & Pleasure Clubs (SAPCs).
Parking:UCLA Lot 4, 398 Westwood Plaza, directly off Sunset Blvd | $12/dayRideshare drop-off, 305 Royce Drive

title: UCLA Film & Television Archive presents: The Sign of the Cross / Only Yesterday
description:
The Sign of the Cross (1932) 
If one film was responsible for the grassroots movement that ended four years of “immoral” pre-Code movies, it was not a film starring Mae West or Norma Shearer. It was a film about early Christians. The Sign of the Cross is based on a reverent 1896 play that Cecil B. DeMille had seen as a youth; in 1932, at 50, he wanted to complete the trilogy he had begun with The Ten Commandments (1923) and The King of Kings (1927). He also needed to revive his stalled career, but the odds were against him, as the Great Depression pushed Paramount (which he had co-founded in 1916) into bankruptcy.
DeMille’s use of symbolism, crowds, crane shots, dialectical montage, contrapuntal sound, music cues, multitrack mixing, and even silence is masterly, surpassing the masterpieces made in 1932 by Ernst Lubitsch, Rouben Mamoulian and Irving Thalberg. The Sign of the Cross has another distinction: it is the most graphically violent and sexually explicit feature yet released by a major studio. “This is the boldest censor-bait ever attempted in a picture,” wrote Variety. Reports from packed theaters confirmed this. “At the Rialto,” wrote the New York Times, “women put their hands across their eyes to shut out the dreadful views; others fainted.”
35mm, b/w, 125 min.
Director: Cecil B. DeMille

Only Yesterday (1933) 
Only Yesterday made a star of an unknown stage actress, Margaret Sullavan, and presented the story of an unwed mother who is both self-determining and unrepentant. And it was one of the first Hollywood features to depict a gay couple, albeit in an incidental manner. Only Yesterday opens with a harrowing depiction of the 1929 stock market crash, the finale of the 1931 book from which Universal borrowed the title. That book treated the 1920s as a distant, regrettable period, the attitude of many pre-Code films, but John Stahl looks at the jazz era with less disdain, basing his film on the wistful Stefan Zweig novel, Letter from an Unknown Woman.
While 1933 had seen a flurry of flagrantly gay characters, Only Yesterday is the only Hollywood film (of its time) to present a gay couple as a matter of fact. Franklin Pangborn is an interior designer who brings his handsome partner (Barry Norton) to a penthouse party. While these characters are supposed to show the decadence of the twenties, they are sympathetically presented.
Only Yesterday was a box office success, one of Universal’s few in 1933, but producer Carl Laemmle Jr. had to fight the Studio Relations Committee (the Production Code office) to retain its gay characters and its heroine’s independence. These plot elements would have been impossible to film a year later, after the Code had been reconstituted. Indeed, the film’s reissue was repeatedly rejected by the Production Code Administration in the mid- to late ’30s.
35mm, b/w, 103 min.
Director: John Stahl
location: UCLA Hammer Museum - Billy Wilder Theater

title: 20th Annual Bruin Run/Walk
description: Bruin Run/Walk at UCLA is a non-profit, student-run organization with the goal to encourage UCLA students to be healthy and exercise by providing them with the opportunity of participating in a 5K Run/Walk on campus. This event raises money for the Chase Child Life Program (CCLP) at UCLA Mattel Children’s Hospital.

title: 17th Annual Latinx Conference
description: This year’s conference will be centered on immigration issues affecting the Latinx community. The conference provides a vital platform and space for professionals, community members, and students from diverse concentrations to engage in learning and critical dialogue regarding influential policies, urban landscapes, evidence based, and community practices that support the Latinx community to overcome challenges led by unjust immigration practices.
location: Public Affairs Building - Patio and Terrace

title: Dressed with Distinction: Syrian Garments for Men and Women
description:
At the end of the 19th century and into the early 20 century, Syrian culture was very diverse in terms of artistic achievement and material culture, and garments worn by wealthier Syrian men and women reflected their rich cosmopolitan lifestyle. Dr. Vogelsang-Eastwood explores economic, political, religious, and social impacts on clothing with an eye to the Fowler Museum’s current installation of garments from the David and Elizabeth Reisbord Collection.
A book signing and reception in the Davis Courtyard will follow.
Cosponsored by the Fowler Museum Textile Council and the Textile Museum Associates of Southern California.
Related Exhibition: Dressed with Distinction: Garments from Ottoman Syria explores the region’s textile production during the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries, when Syria was an international hub for the trade and production of handwoven cloth. With a focus on the social and seasonal contexts in which garments were worn by men, women, and children, the exhibition’s presentation of these distinguished textiles enables audiences to engage with Syrian culture and weaving techniques from a bygone era.
Parking: UCLA Lot 4, 398 Westwood Plaza, directly off Sunset Blvd | $12/dayRideshare drop-off 305 Royce Drive.

title: The American Youth Symphony presents: 54th Annual Gala Concert
description:
Carlos Izcaray, Music Director / Sarah Chang, Violin DMITRI SHOSTAKOVICH: Festive Overture FIL EISLER: World Premiere Violin Concerto, featuring Sarah Chang ANNA CLYNE: This Midnight Hour RICHARD STRAUSS: Der Rosenkavalier
Sarah Chang, widely regarded as one of the greatest violinists of our time, joins AYS for the inaugural Korngold Commission, a project developed and sponsored by Peter Mandell and Sarah Coade Mandell, pairing world-class solo artists with critically acclaimed film composers. The composer in this case is Fil Eisler (aka iZLER), a BMI and SXSW award-winner, best known for scoring hit television series Empire and Revenge.
Along with crowd-pleasing offerings from Shostakovich and Strauss, the program also features This Midnight Hour by Anna Clyne, whose work has been described by the New York Times as “virtuosic,” “inventive,” and “dreamlike.”
7:30P VIP Dinner
After the concert, AYS friends, orchestra members, and guest artists celebrate the continuing success of the American Youth Symphony at the 54th Annual Gala Dinner, our biggest fundraising event of the season. Join AYS in supporting the future of classical music at a sumptuous dinner under the stars!
For more information about this and other Royce Hall events please visit www.roycehall.org. 
Follow Royce Hall on Facebook at UCLA Royce Hall or Twitter @ucla_roycehall

title: UCLA Film & Television Archive presents: Tariki / Tehran: City of Love
description:
Tariki  (Iran, 2018) 
A young woman walks out into the street at night in search of her lover but encounters a mysterious, threatening stranger instead in this short that premiered at Cannes in 2018. DCP, color, 15 min.
Director: Saeed Jafarian.

Tehran: City of Love (2019) 
Three lonely hearts—a bodybuilder, a receptionist and a religious singer—navigate the chilly waters of romance in an alienating urban landscape that puts the irony in the title of writer-director Ali Jaberansari’s second feature. Jaberansa’s deadpan humor and a wry visual style make this an offbeat romantic comedy that suggests it’s the absurdity of pursuing love, not its triumphs, that really makes us human.
DCP, color, 102 min.
Director: Ali Jaberansari.
location: UCLA Hammer Museum - Billy Wilder Theater

title: Graham Haynes In Concert
description:
American cornetist, trumpeter and composer Graham Haynes performs in concert with students who participated in a series of workshops exploring the concept known as “conduction.”* He is an Alpert Award For The Arts nominee and was recently featured on Vijay Iyer's 2017 ECM album, Far From Over. The son of jazz drummer Roy Haynes, Haynes is known for his work in nu jazz, fusing jazz with elements of hip hop and electronic music.
*Conduction®: The practice of conveying and interpreting a lexicon of directives to construct or modify sonic arrangement or composition; a structure-content exchange between composer/conductor and instrumentalists that provides the immediate possibility of initiating or altering harmony, melody, rhythm, tempo, progression, articulation, phrasing or form through the manipulation of pitch, dynamics (volume/intensity/density), timbre, duration, silence, and organization in real-time." – Lawrence D. “Butch” Morris (1947-2013)

title: KCRW Good Food Pie Contest 2019
description: Join KCRW for the Good Food Pie Contest! The celebrated event is back, taking place at Royce Quad, between Royce Hall and Powell Library. For the 10th year in a row, home cooks and professionals alike will compete side-by-side to woo the judges. Once again, the judges will be a collection of LA’s finest chefs and food writers — armed with a fork and on the hunt for Best in Show. Enter a pie, cheer on the competitors, visit the Fowler galleries or just come by and enjoy a slice. Good Food host Evan Kleiman will preside over the afternoon pie festivities which will include music, pie tasting, food trucks, kids’ activities, an artisan marketplace and more. Bring sunscreen, a blanket and relax in the afternoon sun while spending the day with KCRW and the Fowler Museum at UCLA!

title: Concert: UCLA Near East Ensemble with Souhail Kaspar
description:
The Near East Ensemble presents music and instruments from the Arab world, including a performance by master percussionist Souhail Kaspar. Its repertoire includes old court music genres from the Ottoman era, mystical works related to the Sufi Islamic sect, modal and drum improvisations, nightclub pieces, and songs from rural folk celebrations.
Related Exhibition Dressed with Distinction: Garments from Ottoman Syria explores the region’s textile production during the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries, when Syria was an international hub for the trade and production of handwoven cloth. With a focus on the social and seasonal contexts in which garments were worn by men, women, and children, the exhibition’s presentation of these distinguished textiles enables audiences to engage with Syrian culture and weaving techniques from a bygone era.
Parking UCLA Lot 4, 398 Westwood Plaza, directly off Sunset Blvd | $12/dayRideshare drop-off 305 Royce Drive.
location: Fowler - UCLA Art Council Amphitheater - Facility

title: UCLA Film & Television Archive presents: Temporary / Hendi and Hormoz
description:
Temporary  (Iran, 2018) 
Farhang Foundation Short Film Festival Finalist. Shot with a piercing frankness, Temporary confronts us with the hard choices to made by a young, single mother and the willingness of a religious establishment to condone her exploitation.
DCP, color, 16 min.
Directed by Behzad Azadi. Screenwriter: Behzad Azadi

Hendi and Hormoz 
Rugged and delicate beauty exist side-by-side on the red sand island of Hormuz in the Persian Gulf where 13-year-old Hendi is married off to the 16-year-old Hormoz on his promise of a job at the local mine. When the job falls through, the young couple must struggle to make their way against difficult odds in a land as spellbinding as it is unforgiving.
DCP, color, 88 min.
Director Abbas Amini. Screenwriter: Hossein Farrokhzadeh, A. Amini. Cast: Hamed Alipour, Zohreh Eslam, Asma Daneh-chin.
location: UCLA Hammer Museum - Billy Wilder Theater

title: Los Angeles Chamber Orchestra presents Mozart’s Requiem
description:
Join Los Angeles Chamber Orchestra and music director designate Jaime Martín for an intimate performance of Mozart’s Requiem and a West Coast premiere from composer Bryce Dessner.
Los Angeles Chamber Orchestra joins forces with the USC Thornton Singers for a dynamic program led by music director designate, Jaime Martín.
Martín will make his first appearance as the Orchestra’s music director designate conducting Mozart’s Requiem. The concert also features a West Coast premiere Bryce Dessner, a composer and member of the Grammy Award-winning indie rock band The National.
Los Angeles Chamber Orchestra’s vibrant and engaging Orchestral Series showcases the ensemble's remarkable artistry and trademark mix of regal classics and music from today’s leading composers.
For more information about this and other Royce Hall events please visit www.roycehall.org. 
Follow Royce Hall on Facebook at UCLA Royce Hall or Twitter @ucla_roycehall

title: Student Legal Services' 50th Anniversary
description:
Student Legal
Services’ 50th Anniversary Celebration is a reception to highlight
the departments’ many achievements during the last 50 years.  Please RSVP  if you would like to join us!

title: Semel Healthy Campus Initiative Eudaimonia Event
description:
This event will feature a TEDxSalon presentation on compassion as it relates to eudaimonia, the concept of living a life full of purpose and meaning.
The purpose of the event is to promote the idea of eudaimonia by honoring members of the UCLA community who serve as eudaimonic role models by living purposeful and meaningful lives.  The 2019 Semel HCI Eudaimonia honorees will be introduced and recognized for the inspirational and exemplary lives they live.

title: 16th Annual Spanish and Portuguese Graduate Student Association Conference
description: The event will consist of four presentation panels and two keynote addresses. One keynote will be delivered by Professor Erica Pecanha do Nascimento, a specialist in Literatura Marginal a Professor at the University of Sao Paulo. The other keynote will be delivered by three artists from the Bogota Street Art Collective, known by their artist names Toxicomano, Erre, and DJLU.
location: Royce Hall Conf/Seminar -  - Herbert Morris Seminar Room 306

title: Black April Commemoration
description:
This is a unique event commemorating the April 30th anniversary of the fall of Saigon, and provides an educational opportunity for the younger generations to hear the stories of our Vietnamese refugee ancestors. In a generation that lives so far from its original native roots, the Black April Commemoration event is especially significant because we strongly believe that heritage and culture are integral parts of the Vietnamese identity.
By commemorating this monumental event in Vietnamese history, we hope to remind everyone of how much our ancestors have sacrificed to come to America and strive for better opportunities for themselves and their children. Ultimately, we want to shed light on the many diverse perspectives of those affected by the war and bring about a memorable, personal, and enlightening experience to all.
 
Traditionally, the commemoration event features a combination of the following:


Free dinner
Panel of community speakers
History showcase (art, photographs, poems)
Candle lighting ceremony

title: Farmers' Market at UCLA
description: The UCLA Farmers' Markets serve as a convenient location for members of the UCLA community to purchase good produce from many local farmers. Come check it out!
location: Bruin Plaza - Stage and Bruin Bear Areas

title: Luskin Lecture: A Conversation with Teddy Cruz and Fonna Forman
description: Part of the UCLA Luskin Lecture Series, Teddy Cruz and Fonna Forman are invited to speak on Justice and Urban Design.
location: Kerckhoff Hall Venue - Charles E. Young Grand Salon (248)

title: Fowler Out Loud
description:
Music composition PhD student Giovanni Piacentini presents an evening of original compositions for solo guitar and electronics, through which he explores the instruments’ sonic capabilities in a quest to expand their dynamic and expressive range.The program will include the Chiaroscuro suite from his 2017 debut album and brand-new works from his upcoming album Between Worlds due out in April 2019.
Fowler Out Loud is an evening concert series that invites UCLA students from various disciplines to perform at the museum. Support for Fowler Out Loud comes from the UCLA Office of Residential Life.
All performances begin at 6PM. Galleries are open until 8PM.

title: 4th Annual CISA Graduate Student Conference and Annual Lecture
description:
Graduate student paper presentations on various topics on South Asia
Keynote address will be provided by: Professor Vinay Gidwani, University of Minnesota
location: Young Research Library - Main Conference Room 11360

title: UCLA Pow Wow 2019
description: The UCLA pow wow is a gathering of Native American peoples to compete in traditional dance and singing. Vendors sell Indigenous crafts, jewelry, and food outside of drum circle.

title: UCLA Relay for Life 2019: To a Cure and Beyond!
description:
Relay for Life is a 24-hour fundraiser for the American Cancer Society (ACS) held annually at UCLA Drake Stadium. Relay is centered on celebrating loved ones currently battling or having battled cancer, remembering loved ones lost to cancer, and fighting back against a disease that affects every one of us in some way.
During the span of 24 hours, we play games, watching amazing artists perform, have a 5k run/walk, and dance for hours at our 2am silent rave, all while raising money for ACS. ACS provides many services such as rides to chemotherapy, lodging for those undergoing chemotherapy, increasing awareness and education, and lobby for policies that benefit cancer patients.

title: The Bruin Experiment Science Fair
description: A science fair for middle school students, judged by UCLA faculty. Come enjoy some refreshments and talk to the students about their projects!

title: Israel in 3D Community Conference
description: Prominent Israeli and American speakers will explore "cross-border" connections between the two countries in three major areas - Entertainment, Religion and Business & Technology.
location: Sunset Village - Covel Grand Horizon & Terrace

title: UCLA Pow Wow 2019
description: The UCLA pow wow is a gathering of Native American peoples to compete in traditional dance and singing. Vendors sell Indigenous crafts, jewelry, and food outside of drum circle.

title: Slavic, East European & Eurasian Languages & Cultures - Michael Heim Memorial Lecture
description:
The UCLA Department of Slavic, East European & Eurasian Languages & Cultures 
and the UCLA Department of Comparative Literature invite you to attend the 6th Annual Michael Henry Heim Memorial Lecture featuring “Epic Foolishness: Translating Epic Poetry for the 21st Century” (tentative) by Bill Johnston, Professor of Comparative Literature at Indiana University Bloomington.
location: Royce Hall Conf/Seminar - - Humanities Conf Room 314

title: Fowler Out Loud
description:
Trained in North and South Indian classical music, Pragathi Guruprasad is an Indian-American playback singer—one who provides the voice-over soundtrack lip-synched by actors. Raised in Fremont, CA, she was featured in the third season of the reality-based singing competition Airtel Super Singer Junior (2012) and has since recorded for over a dozen Tamil-language films and albums.
Fowler Out Loud is an evening concert series that invites UCLA students from various disciplines to perform at the museum. Support for Fowler Out Loud comes from the UCLA Office of Residential Life.
All performances begin at 6PM. Galleries are open until 8PM.

title: Bruin Day for Transfer Students 2019
description:
UCLA Bruin Day is an exclusive, annual event designed especially for admitted transfer students and their families to learn about our world-class academic programs, research opportunities and financial aid resources, take campus and housing tours, and experience what it means to be a Bruin. UCLA is yours to discover!
Multiple campus locations.

title: UCLA Film & Television Archive presents: Ill Fate
description:
Ill Fate  (Iran, 2018)
This long-overdue documentary explores the role and image of women in Iranian cinema from its beginnings around 1900 up to the year of the Revolution. Fascinating research and insight illuminates dozens of clips from rare and classic titles.
DCP, color and b/w, 88 min.
Director: Sahar Khoshnam
location: UCLA Hammer Museum - Billy Wilder Theater

title: Peter Hessler Talk
description: Peter Hessler is an American writer and journalist. He is the author of four acclaimed books about China and has contributed numerous articles to The New Yorker and National Geographic, among other publications. In 2011, Hessler received a MacArthur Foundation "genius grant" in recognition and encouragement of his "keenly observed accounts of ordinary people responding to the complexities of life in such rapidly changing societies as Reform Era China."
location: Young Research Library - Main Conference Room 11360

title: Farmers' Market at UCLA
description: The UCLA Farmers' Markets serve as a convenient location for members of the UCLA community to purchase good produce from local farmers.  Come check it out!
location: Bruin Plaza - Stage and Bruin Bear Areas

title: Synthesis Dance Theatre Performance
description: Happenings Event Not FoundThe Happenings event you are trying to view is no longer available. Please try a different search.Return to Happenings home page.

title: Brokering the Sacred: A Panel on the Ethics of Collecting Native Art
description:
The repatriation of Native arts over the last 30 years has demonstrated the sustainability of Indigenous knowledge and survivance strategies. How might this moment speak to the viability of the arts as cultural transmitters rather than solely objects of capital worth? The ethics of collecting Native arts are debated by a panel of experts, including Mercedes Dorame, Tongva artist; Sven D. Haakanson, Associate Professor, Department of Anthropology, University of Washington; Andrew Meyer, Visiting Graduate Researcher at UCLA Latin American Institute and Coordinator of the California Hub of the Institut des Amériques; Wendy Teeter, Curator of Archaeology, Fowler Museum; and Nancy Marie Mithlo, Professor, Department of Gender Studies.
Please join us before the lecture for a light welcome reception from 5:00-6:00pm. 
Copresented by the UCLA American Indian Studies Center, the UCLA Institute of American Cultures, and the California Hub of the Institut des Amériques.
Parking available in UCLA Lot 4, 398 Westwood Plaza, directly off Sunset Blvd | $12/day. Rideshare drop-off 305 Royce Drive.

title: Fowler Out Loud
description:
Suburban is an independent rock band originally from Victorville, CA and currently based in Los Angeles. Formed by Werner von Der Heide (guitar/vocals), the band line-up consists of Scotty Adler (guitar), Amanda Glover (bass), and Daniel Wefers (drums). Suburban will perform new songs from their recently released third album, Sober Daytime Naps Make Vivid Dreamsand other original material.
Fowler Out Loud is an evening concert series that invites UCLA students from various disciplines to perform at the museum. Support for Fowler Out Loud comes from the UCLA Office of Residential Life.
All performances begin at 6PM. Galleries are open until 8PM.

title: UCLA Blood Drive
description: Annual "I Heart UCLA" blood drive.
location: Ackerman Union Meeting Room - Viewpoint Conference Rooms 1&2 (A201A&B)

title: DMA MFA FINAL EXHIBITION
description:
DMA MFA Final Exhibition is the Graduate Student presentation of their art work.

Hye Min Cho

title: 19th Annual UCLA Brain Tumor Conference
description:
The UCLA Brain Tumor Center will be hosting the 19th Annual UCLA Brain Tumor Conference for patients, families, caregivers and healthcare professionals. This educational conference will offer participants the opportunity to hear leading healthcare professionals speak about the latest treatments for brain tumors, symptom management, community resources and social support. Representatives from brain tumor organizations, health agencies and support groups will also be available to offer vital information and resources catering to the brain tumor community.
Speakers will include:

Dr. Timothy Cloughesy (UCLA Neuro-Oncology)
Dr. Leia Nghiemphu (UCLA Neuro-Oncology)
Dr. Albert Lai (UCLA Neuro-Oncology)
Dr. Richard Everson (UCLA Neurosurgery)
Dr. Won Kim (UCLA Neurosurgery)
Dr. Tom Davidson (UCLA Pediatric Neuro-Oncology)
Dr. William Yong (UCLA Neuropathology)
Dr. Tania Kaprealian (UCLA Radiation Oncology)

title: Music of India and Music of the Balkans Ensembles
description:
The Music of India Ensemble and The Music of the Balkans Ensemble showcase traditional music from these regions on the same stage. Performances will include short compositions of North Indian classical and semi-classical ragas (harmonic modes) and talas (rhythmic patterns on tabla or drums) and Bulgarian traditional songs and music.
Students of Rahul Neuman will play the sitar (a long-necked lute with seven principal strings, plus 12 to 20 sympathetic strings) and the students of Abhiman Kaushal will perform on the tabla for The Music of India Ensemble. The Music of the Balkans Ensemble focuses on Bulgarian traditional and contemporary music with a wedding orchestra of modern instruments and two choirs that sing traditional songs with modern arrangements.

title: UCLA Alumni Day
description:
In its early years UCLA was dubbed “the twig,” an offshoot of the University of California created to serve the state’s rapidly growing population. The sapling took hold, each graduating class strengthening the roots boring deep into the bedrock. Every breakthrough, discovery and stride fortified the trunk and sent its branches skyward. And as UCLA’s alumni, faculty and students made their mark in the world they loaded each bough with magnificent leaves of accomplishment, flowers of wisdom and the sweet fruit of hope. UCLA - a twig no more. Come back to campus and celebrate with fellow Bruins. Reconnect with friends and enjoy a panoply of engaging performances, sessions and tours.
UCLA Alumni Day will commemorate our first hundred years and anticipate the endlessly bright possibilities of the future.

title: 19th Annual UCLA Brain Tumor Conference
description:
The UCLA Brain Tumor Center will be hosting the 19th Annual UCLA Brain Tumor Conference for patients, families, caregivers and healthcare professionals. This educational conference will offer participants the opportunity to hear leading healthcare professionals speak about the latest treatments for brain tumors, symptom management, community resources and social support. Representatives from brain tumor organizations, health agencies and support groups will also be available to offer vital information and resources catering to the brain tumor community.

title: TEDxUCLA
description: TEDxUCLA will have 15 speakers for an educational 1 day conference in Royce Hall. For more information, please visit tedx.ucla.edu

title: Music of Java and Music of Thailand Ensembles
description:
The Music of Java (Javanese Gamelan) and Music of Thailand ensembles will perform traditional music highlighting their shared cultural history. Students of master Javanese musician Pak Djoko Walujo will perform Central Javanese gamelan, a percussion-dominated musical ensemble featuring tuned bronze gongs, bronze metallophones, and drums, along with flutes, zither, vocals, and spike fiddle. Venerable Dark Cloud, the name of UCLA’s Javanese gamelan, is one of the first sets of non-Western instruments that renowned UCLA ethnomusicologist Mantle Hood brought back to the United States.
In honor of the historical musical exchange between Indonesia and Thailand, the Music of Java Ensemble will perform a composition that originated in Thailand, Ladrang Siyem (Siam).
Immediately following, the Music of Thailand Ensemble, led by Supeena Insee Adler, will perform the Java Overture, a well-known Thai composition inspired by gamelan music from Indonesia. The Music of Thailand Ensemble was founded by David Morton, who was a student of Mantle Hood while he was at UCLA. The Music of Thailand Ensemble performance will feature dance and singing accompanied by instruments including gong circles, xylophones, flute and stringed instruments, such as three-stringed zither, two-stringed fiddle and three-stringed spike fiddle.

title: Music of Bali and African American Music Ensemble
description:
Music of Bali Ensemble
I Nyoman Wenten, director
The Music of Bali Ensemble features gamelan music (the generic Indonesian word for orchestra) and dance. The Balinese gamelan gong kebyar is famous for its fast tempos, abrupt changes of texture, and brilliantly costumed dancers who act out stories from the Hindu Ramayana.
African American Music Ensemble
James Roberson, director
Grammy-nominee James Roberson and The African American Music Ensemble perform gospel music, including Negro spirituals and traditional and contemporary gospel music.

title: Fowler Out Loud
description:
This South Asian double-feature will showcase a unique collaboration between the award-winning competitive South Asian classical dance team UCLA Taara and Naya Zamaana, UCLA's premier South Asian acappella team. UCLA Taara combines several Indian classical dance styles to create innovative routines, while Naya Zamaana performs arrangements infused with Bollywood and western popular music to create a fusion unique to the world of a cappella.
Fowler Out Loud is an evening concert series that invites UCLA students from various disciplines to perform at the museum. Support for Fowler Out Loud comes from the UCLA Office of Residential Life.
All performances begin at 6PM. Galleries are open until 8PM. 
Parking UCLA Lot 4, 398 Westwood Plaza, directly off Sunset Blvd | $12/dayRideshare drop-off 305 Royce Drive.
location: Fowler - UCLA Art Council Amphitheater - Facility

title: FAST Runway Pre-Party
description: FAST at UCLA will be hosting a Runway Pre-Party in order to publicize the FAST Annual Runway Show the week after (5/30/19). We will have a photo booth, giveaways, and music. We will also selling FAST T-shirts, designed by our Creative team, to fundraise for our Runway Show.

title: Semel Healthy Campus Initiative Center 2019 Celebration
description: The annual Semel Healthy Campus Initiative Celebration highlights the wellbeing research and work conducted by students, faculty and staff in building a culture of health on campus, demonstrates the work of the HCI pods and recognizes HCI supporters who have made significant contributions to the success of Semel HCI.  The theme of the celebration is Health in Harmony and will feature music performances, and the presentation of the Jane B Semel Appreciation Awards.
location: Sunset Canyon Recreation Ctr. - Amphitheater Lawn

title: Anderson Luncheon Bhagwan Chowdhry - Fowler Terrace
description: Happenings Event Not FoundThe Happenings event you are trying to view is no longer available. Please try a different search.Return to Happenings home page.

title: An Evening of Magic
description: Yearly magic show hosted by UCLA student-run magic club
location: Kerckhoff Hall Venue - Charles E. Young Grand Salon (248)

title: Old-Time String Band and Music of Mexico Ensemble
description:
Old-Time String Band
David Bragger, director
The Old-Time String Band Ensemble performs traditional music of rural America. This ensemble delves into the exciting old-time sub-genres of Appalachian fiddle and banjo music, Mid-West fiddle tunes, North Carolina and Georgia string band music, Cajun/Creole fiddle, traditional bluegrass, country blues, and jug band music, to name a few. This is the early country music of America in its crooked, colorful, droney, funky, lonesome, soulful, danceable, and back porch glory.
Music of Mexico Ensemble
Jesús Guzmán, director
The Music of Mexico Ensemble, under the direction of 2008 Grammy winner Jesús Guzmán, features mariachi music in a variety of styles from various regions of Mexico, including son jalisiense, son huasteco, bolero, ranchera and huapango.

title: Design Showcase West - Public Review Session
description: Design Showcase West, created by the UCLA School of Theater, Film and Television, is the only national entertainment design showcase on the West Coast featuring the work of graduate students from the nation's top university design programs. Exhibits range from costume design to scenic, sound, lighting and production design. Studio executives, film and television producers, theater artistic directors and professional designers attend DSW to meet the industry's fresh rising stars.

title: Near East Ensemble and Music of China Ensemble
description:
Near East Ensemble
A. J. Racy, director
The Near East Ensemble presents music and instruments from the Arab world. Its repertoire includes old court music genres from the Ottoman era, mystical works related to the Sufi Islamic sect, modal and drum improvisations, nightclub pieces, and songs from rural folk celebrations.
Music of China Ensemble
Chi Li, director
The Music of China Ensemble performs arias from Kun opera of the 16th century, “silk-and-bamboo” wind and string music from the Shanghai area, folk dances for festive celebration, zheng zither music in the Keijia style from Canton Province, music for large percussion ensembles, and modern compositions for traditional Chinese wind and string ensembles.

title: Yukai Daiko 15th Annual Spring Showcase
description: Come join Yukai Daiko (Japanese drumming) for our 15th annual spring showcase!

title: Music and Dance of West Africa and Persian Music Ensemble
description:
Music and Dance of West Africa Ensemble
Francis Awe and Omawale Orishayomi, co-directors
The Music of West Africa Ensemble performs the music and dances of the Yoruba people of Nigeria. The ensemble produces complex polyphonic textures on a variety of drums, bells and rattles to accompany dramatic and entertaining social dances.
Persian Music Ensemble
Amir Pourjavady, director
The Persian Music Ensemble focuses on the performance of Persian classical music including the radif and tasnifs (vocal repertoire).
This program is made possible in part by the Elahé Omidyar Mir-Djalali Fund for Iranian Music established by Roshan Cultural Heritage Institute, and the generosity of the Farhang Foundation.

title: UCLA Jazz Combos Concert
description: The UCLA Jazz Combos Concert features student jazz combos performing standards and original works. Directed by Clayton Cameron, Charley Harrison, Roberto Miranda, Charles Owens, and Michele Weir and with special guests the Herbie Hancock Institute of Jazz Performance Ensemble at UCLA, the combos range in size from three to 10 musicians, allowing student musicians the opportunity to explore composition and improvisation more intensely.

title: 14th Annual Spring Swing Dance feat Swing Inc.
description:
7:30pm Swing Dance Lessons for Beginners & Swing Dance Party
9pm-11:30pm featuring professional ten piece band, Swing Inc. plus singers Directed by Dennis Kaye. UCLA student singers will perform with band.
10:10pm-10:30pm Additional Student Dance/A Cappella and Professional Dance group performances during band break.
Complimentary Refreshments from ASUCLA Catering for participants.

title: UCLA Big Band Concert
description:
The UCLA Latin Jazz Big Band, the Contemporary Jazz Ensemble, the Charles Mingus Ensemble, and the UCLA Jazz Orchestra, directed by world-class jazz artists, will be performing well-known jazz standards as well as compositions by the faculty directors and the students.
The Latin Jazz Big Band is directed by Paul De Castro, who is highly regarded as a pianist and instructor of both jazz and Afro-Cuban (salsa) styles, and has just released a new CD, Bueno Pá Gozar: Paul De Castro y su Orquesta Dengue. The Contemporary Jazz Ensemble and the Charles Mingus Ensemble are directed by Hitomi Oba, co-founder of the composer/performer new music collective L.A. Signal Lab. The UCLA Jazz Orchestra is directed by Charley Harrison, whose recently released album, Keeping My Composure, maintained a spot on the charts of JazzWeek for 13 consecutive weeks.

title: DMA SENIOR EXHIBITION
description: DMA Senior Exhibition showcases the work of graduating undergraduates.

title: UCLA Commencement Ceremony
description:
UCLA welcomes its graduating students and their families and friends to Commencement ceremonies and activities.
For detailed information on everything from graduation ceremony schedules and locations to ceremony site maps and parking information, please visit the UCLA Commencement web site or the Commencement Mobile App.

title: Tai Chi with Master Peter Asco
description:
Originating from ancient Chinese Taoist principles, Tai Chi is a martial art form that helps create a healthy balance of yin (internal energy) and yang (external energy). Master Peter Asco leads a free Tai Chi lesson with basic training in Chi Kung in the David Courtyard.
No registration or experience necessary.

title: Constitution Day 2019
description: On Constitution Day, the UCLA community pauses to commemorate the drafting of the U.S. Constitution. Read the actual words of the Founding Fathers on the University of California Constitution Day website.

title: Bruin Day 2020
description: UCLA Bruin Day is an exclusive, annual event designed especially for admitted freshmen and their families to enjoy faculty presentations, learn about our world-class academic programs, research opportunities and financial aid resources, take campus and housing tours, and experience what it means to be a Bruin. UCLA is yours to discover! Multiple locations on campus.
